utterances: Let's see if we can get another caller on.
And this is Calvin(ph), Calvin with us from Michigan.
How are you doing?
Very well, thank you.
What kind of politician did she already prove herself to be at that point?
I just want to get your guest to comment on whether the system, or how the system work to impede or to assist them in their reintegration back into society.
I served 15 years in the Michigan State Penitentiary for robbery.
And as I begin to get close to coming home, I started putting away money.
And I put away about $800, and I intended to use this money to ease myself back into society.
This was from a prison job.
Yes, from a prison job, right.
And it's hard.
You don't make a lot of money in there.
So this is about three years worth of savings.
And, you know, I wanted to use this money to get back - to ease myself back into society, maybe rent a home or room or something like that.
And I thought that I was unable to get that money for too much, and this is typical.
And they don't provide you with ID and things that you just normally need to reintegrate and get back into society.
You know, you apply for a job, you need identification.
And it seems to me like the system could do more to assist in your integration back into society.
Jackie Smith, is that right?
You don't have any ID when you get out?

I agree 100 percent because it was so - I mean, when I came home, I went to, like, three DMVs before one of the supervisors actually felt sorry for me, and was like, let me see what she got, because I have my prison ID.

You don't suppose to bring it out, but I snuck it out anyway because I figured it will be a help to help me get ID because all I had was my birth certificate and my Social Security card, which I sent off for prior to me being released.
And they sent it back.
The counselors give it back to you when you get ready to leave.
And I had these documents, the release papers they gave me plus the ID card, and I took it.
You know, this is all I have, you know, and a letter from the halfway house.
And they would not give it to me.
And the lady was, like, let me see what she got.
And she was like, give it to her, because that was like the third DMV that I have went to, and it was like you don't have enough points.
And they was, like, oh no, that's a federal ID card.
If you had state ID, we will honor it because there is some agreement with the state that they have.
Right.
If you have state ID, then you can get your driver's - you know, a New York state ID.
And Jackie, you're now a kitchen manager.
Yes.
You've got a good job.
Mm-hmm.
Have you been able to get a credit card?
Yes, I have.
I mean, it took time.
It took time.
At first, everywhere deny me, deny me.
But overtime, I established myself and, you know, that my first credit card, $100 limit.
I said, okay, that's a start, you know?
And I've just, you know, been doing better.
I've been doing much better.
Calvin, thanks very much for the call.
Good question.
All right.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
And as you look ahead, Jacqueline Smith, how did you get that job as a kitchen manager and it sounds like it wasn't easy for you either.
No, it wasn't.
But in the halfway house, they had a coordinator that would set people up with jobs.
And the first job I had was at a clothing store in the city.
And I like the job.
It was pretty good.
But I, you know, I love being in the kitchen so that's something I wanted to do.
And he said the company that I was working for at the time was hiring.
So, I went down there.
You know, I didn't know what to say because like I said I've been locked up for 10 years.
I mean, what do I put on the application?
Do I put all the jobs I did in prison?
Or do I - you know, I mean, where do I go?
I mean, I was just lost for what information to put down there because I didn't want them to see, okay, prison, okay where is this?
Everything was in prison for the last 10 years.
So, I mean - but I just sat down before I even filled out the application and spoke to him.
But then, the counselor had already told, you know, the employer about the situation, so he already knew.
You know, so that helped out too.
And then, you know, they don't have - he didn't have a problem with hiring me.
And when they did the interview, you know, the manager, he was like, you know, I got a good feeling about you.
And, you know, they gave me a chance.
And I worked for that company for like five years.
Well, congratulations and good luck to you.
Thank you.
Jackie Smith joined us from New York.
She served 10 years in a federal prison for interstate drug trafficking, and talked about her problems with reconnecting with her family and finding a job.
There are one-in-five prisoners who have a job lined up upon their release according to the Urban Institute.
And according, again, the Bureau of Labor - Bureau of Justice statistics in 2003, 68 percent of state prisoners lack a high school diploma.
And according to the last study done - and that was back in 1994 - more than two-thirds of prisoners released are rearrested within three years.
Joining us now is Roland Acevedo.
He was convicted of armed robbery on two separate occasions and spent about 10 years in jail altogether.
He's currently an attorney in private practice with Seiff Kretz & Abercrombie in New York City.
And he joins us now from the studios of member station WFUV on the campus of Fordham University in the Bronx.
And welcome to TALK OF THE NATION.
Thank you, Neal.
And you're a repeat offender, as we just mentioned there.
How quickly after your first release were you charged and convicted again?
In 60 days.
I was back so quickly that some of my friends didn't even know I left.
And that's sadly the case with too many people who get out of prison.
And tomorrow on this program, we'll hear from Bangladesh, where the T-shirt was cut and sewn.
Well, that goes to the whole issue with there being an adequate transition period.
So some people are not prepared to go from a very structured setting in prison to society.
So when you - when it's unleashed on you, there's a frustration fact that that leads you back to the same behavior that put you in prison in the first place.
But as we also mentioned, you're an attorney.
How did that happen?
Lot of hard work, plenty of luck, and lots of support by, you know, people who have established themselves in the legal community.
We're talking with Roland Acevedo.
He's our guest.
He's a former prisoner convicted of armed robbery on two separate occasions.
He's now an attorney and working in private practice in New York City.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION coming to you from NPR News.
And Roland, did you have problems of finding housing or reconnecting with your family after you were released?
I did, Neal.

When I first got out - when I got out the second time because there was nothing to talk about getting out the first time, I was back so quickly, but when I got out the second time, I planned to go into a homeless-type program out in Long Island.
But my parents picked me up, and on the way to the shelter, you know, my dad and mom suggested that I just come home and stay with them.
They had a one bedroom, so I was sleeping on the couch.
But I was happy.
I was very happy to have the couch.
I wasn't complaining.
Hmm.
Now, let's see if we can get some more - here is an e-mail we have from Jonathan(ph) in Tallahassee.
I've heard many inmates who may even receive professional training in prison are unable to practice a large number of professions because they're legally barred from getting a license.
I was wondering if any of the panelists have dealt with this problem.
Yeah, I represent lots of people who have licensing problems, including some lawyers.

I recently worked on a case where a person with a similar criminal background as mine was admitted as an attorney in New Jersey but has been denied repeatedly when he has tried for admission here in New York.
So I've worked on a couple of cases like that.
I've testified it at various character committees for people with felony backgrounds who are applying to be attorneys.
So I see that often.
Let's get Jane(ph) on the line.
Jane is calling us from California.
Hi.
Hello.
Hi, Jane.
Thanks for taking my call.
Go ahead.
